Qst.Quest: if he will list the projects which he is submitting for EC funding under the ENVIREG programme; and the steps which he is taking to ensure that Ireland gets maximum benefit from funds under this programme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: The EC Commission adopted the ENVIREG initiative on 3 May 1990 and operational programmes must be submitted to the Commission within six months of that date. The Commission has already been fully briefed on Ireland's need for support for environmental measures of the kind covered by this initiative. A programme is now being prepared in consultation with the EC Commission but it would not be appropriate at this stage to list the projects which may be submitted. However, the Government indicated its intention, in the environment action programme, to seek support from the EC, including support under ENVIREG, for the new programme to eliminate untreated discharges of sewage from major coastal towns.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - US Citizens Voting Rights.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if he will clarify the position of the voting rights of United States citizens who are permanently domiciled in this country.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: A citizen of the United States who is ordinarily resident here is entitled to be registered as a local government elector and to vote at local elections. If the person concerned is also a citizen of Ireland he would, in addition, be entitled to vote at Dáil, Presidential and European elections and referenda.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if he will give consideration to putting candidates' photographs on ballot papers in order to assist illiterate, visually impaired, dyslexic and handicapped people to cast their votes at election time; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: I have no proposals at present to amend the law to provide for the inclusion of a photograph of a candidate on the ballot paper at an election.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Monitoring of Maternity Patients.

Qst.Quest: the steps which the National Maternity Hospital, Dublin 2 have taken to review the procedures relating to the monitoring of maternity patients in labour and post-delivery.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will appreciate, it is vitally important that any hospital should have, and be seen to have, the full confidence of the public who avail of its services and who, in the case of a public voluntary hospital, as taxpayers provide the bulk of its finances.

A situation has now arisen where the circumstances surrounding the tragic case of the Dunne family have given rise to comment which might undermine public confidence in the overall services provided by the hospital. As I indicated in my reply to an earlier question on this issue, if the circumstances of this or any other case point to the need for a review of polices or procedures in a particular service it will be dealt with as part of an overall review of the service concerned.
I reiterated these views and my concern that public confidence in the hospital should not be undermined when I met recently with the deputy chairman and the master of the hospital.

I was pleased therefore to learn last week of the decision by the hospital to invite a distinguished nominee of the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists from the United Kingdom to undertake within the coming weeks an independent review of the hospital's practices and procedures.

Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself that he continues to receive accurate information from the board of Beaumont Hospital regarding recent controversies in neurosurgery; that the Church and General Insurance Company will continue to provide insurance cover at the hospital; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I have had no reason to doubt the accuracy of any information which I or my Department received from the board or their officers of Beaumont Hospital concerning the hospital's neuro-surgical services. If the Deputy has evidence to the contrary, he should, of course, ensure that the information is made available.

MainHeading.P: The question of insurance cover is a matter for the hospital. I understand that there has been no change in the arrangements provided by the insurance company mentioned by the Deputy.

Qst.Quest: the names of all the members of the Drug Advisory Board; if he considers that they have adequate experience of natural medicine as members of this board; and, if not, whether he will consider addressing this matter in the future.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The members of the National Drugs Advisory Board are as follows: Professor K. O'Malley (Chairman); Dr. M. Curtin; Mr. T. McGuinn; Mr. P.F. Nowlan; Dr. J. Stronge; Professor R. F. Timoney; Dr. K. McGarry; Mr. M. C. Gaynor; Dr. A. Meade; Dr. G. Fitzgerald; Dr. T. V. O'Dwyer; Dr. P. D. O'Mahony; and Professor G.G. Shaw.
The functions of the National Drugs Advisory Board include the assessment of all medicines in relation to their safety, efficacy and quality.

When making appointments to the National Drugs Advisory Board, I have to have regard to a number of factors, including the functions of the board as prescribed. The final composition of the board must be representative of appropriate professional and technical interests and also capable of carrying out its functions to the highest standard possible.
The Deputy can be assured that I have had and will continue to have regard to the need for appropriate experience and expertise when making appointments to this board.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Donegal River Pollution.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the concern expressed by the people of Inishowen regarding the continued pollution of the River Foyle, which is due, in part, to the waste of Altnagelvin Hospital being deposited there; and the steps which are being taken to prevent Donegal from being the garbage disposal outlet of the Department of the Environment of Northern Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I am aware of public concern arising out of the discovery of hospital clinical waste from Altnagelvin Hospital, Derry which washed ashore along parts of the Donegal coast along Lough Foyle.

The North Western Health Board's community medical staff and environmental health officers met with staff responsible for public health in the Derry area when the source of the waste was identified. They received assurances from the Western Health and Social Services Board in Northern Ireland that new procedures put in place in Derry will ensure that there is no recurrence of the problem.

Donegal County Council which is the authority responsible for dealing with sanitary services including waste disposal have, with the assistance of the health board, collected the waste and returned it to the Northern Ireland authorities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Regional Sports Centres.

Qst.Quest: if work will commence on the proposed regional sports centres in 1990; and the amount of finance allocated to the centres in 1990.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The following nine locations were designed as regional sports centres by the Government in 1988: Waterford; Limerick (Thomond College); Sligo; Cork; Athlone; Galway; National Badminton Centre, Baldoyle; National Basketball Centre, Tallaght and Morton Stadium, Santry. The total allocation for the regional centres is £9.35 million.
The current position in relation to each project is as follows:
Waterford Allocation £0.5 million

A 400 metre, eight lane synthetic running track to full international standards together with the development of the infield area, fencing, lighting, car parking and access road has been completed with grant aid of £0.4 million. Proposals for the provision of athletic equipment and for toilets and changing facilities are being finalised by Waterford Corporation. It is expected that these works for which grant aid of £0.1 million is available will be completed in 1990.
Limerick (Thomond College) Allocation £0.9 million

Work will commence shortly on the refurbishment of the athletic track at Thomond College at a cost of approximately £700,000. A fully equipped sports science laboratory for the testing of top class athletes will also be provided from this allocation. In addition a sports related building comprising of squash-handball courts and changing areas is being provided adjacent to the track funded entirely by Thomond fundraising activities and local sources. It is anticipated that the allocation of £900,000 will be expended fully on these developments in 1990.
Cork Allocation £1.75 million;
Sligo Allocation £1.0 million

MainHeading.P: Development consortia have been invited to submit proposals on a design, construct and manage basis for these projects which comprise of two 25 metre swimming pools. The projects will also include the provision of additional indoor and outdoor sport and leisure facilities financed by the consortium of the designated sites. Following this invitation a number of consortia will be shortlisted to proceed to the detailed design stage. It is expected that construction work will commence in 1990.
Galway Allocation £1.5 million;
Athlone Allocation £1.5 million

My Department is in consultation with the local authorities in relation to the range and location of the facilities to be provided in these centres. These discussions will be completed at an early date with a view to construction work commencing in 1990.
Baldoyle Allocation £100,00

Work has been completed and the total allocation expended with the exception of a small retention amount. This facility comprises an eight court badminton facility complete with spectator and office accommodation, changing and showering facilities.
National Basketball Centre, Tallaght Allocation £800,000

The Irish Basketball Association have prepared preliminary plans for the project and are finalising acquisition of a suitable site. On receipt of planning permission, the remaining planning work can be completed. It is not possible however at this stage to say when construction work will commence.
Morton Stadium, Santry Allocation £1.3 million

Plans are being prepared for the refurbishment of the athletic track which will include lighting, drainage, changing and toilet facilities. It is not possible to give an exact date for commencement of construction.

Qst.Quest: if a site has been acquired for the National Indoor Sports Stadium, and if so, when work will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The Custom House Docks Development Authority, who are acting as agents for my Department on the National Sports Centre, have acquired or have agreed terms for approximately 68 per cent of the twelve acre site. Acquisition of the remainder of the site is the subject of a compulsory purchase order.
The outcome of the public hearing on the CPO which was held in February 1990 is expected shortly.
It is not possible at this stage to give a date for commencement of construction.
